captions.text:
At this point, most of us are familiar with
the term Marvel Cinematic Universe, or MCU.

It refers to the multiple films produced by
Marvel Studios that tell one big interwoven

story. But as that story continues, it's becoming
clear that we could also call this the Robert

Downey Jr Cinematic Universe! How did that
happen, and what does it mean going forward?

Let's discuss! Now interestingly, when it
came to making the very first movie from Marvel

Studios - the big bang of the Marvel Cinematic
Universe - casting Robert Downey Jr was considered

a bit of a gamble. He was forty-three at the
time, older than the usual actor asked to

anchor a new franchise, and hadn't starred
in a box office hit since - well - Back to

School in 1986. But ultimately director Jon
Favreau felt Downey's real life struggle with

substance abuse made him the best choice to
not only make a difficult character like Tony

Stark likeable, but portray him with some
actual emotional depth. Favreau went to bat

for Downey and Kevin Feige agreed in what
would be Marvel's first gamble of many - to

pay off! Iron Man was a huge hit, and after
similar outside of the box casting with Edward

Norton as Bruce Banner failed to yield the
same results, Marvel's only success through

2010, when Iron Man 2 hit theaters. That film
was also a box office success, although not

as well received by fans. Still, it far outperformed
the debut of two new members to the MCU, Thor

and Captain America - both in 2011. By the
time Joss Whedon's The Avengers hit theaters,

Downey had become an invaluable part of the
MCU and the ensemble film leaned on him heavily

- in some ways, another Iron Man film. And
Downey's luck also continued, as Whedon decided

to pair up his Stark with the other scientist
on the team, the new Bruce Banner played by

Mark Ruffalo. Ruffalo was tremendously well-received
in the role, as was his relationship with

Stark - the internet went nuts for the Science
Bros! And finally shippers had an alternative

to all the Loki-Thor fantasies out there.
Hey, the fan hearts want what the fan hearts

want... Then, further proving that Downey
is the spine of the Marvel Cinematic Universe,

Iron Man 3 - with Favreau replaced by Downey
pal Shane Black at Downey's request - hit

theaters and closely mirrored the astounding
success of The Avengers! And this, this is

where things started to really take a turn
in Downey's favor - by his design. Despite

its financial success, Iron Man 3 again rubbed
fans the wrong way, even more so than Iron

Man 2. And Downey's contract with Marvel had
run out. While promoting Iron Man 3, Downey

was very vocal that this might be the end
of his run, causing the industry and fans

alike to wonder what the MCU would look like
without him. But Marvel didn't want to wonder,

so they cut a deal with Downey for an undisclosed
sum. Not for more Iron Man movies though,

as Downey made it clear he was in The Avengers
business - he could see that team movies were

the future, especially for Marvel. And speaking
of team movies, Downey saw to it that HE would

be at the heart of the most hotly anticipated
Marvel movie on the horizon, Avengers 2 Age

of Ultron. Fans couldn't believe it when it
seemed that in the movies it would be Downey's

Stark and not Hank Pym who creates Ultron,
as Pym does so famously in the comics, and

there was some fear that Mandarin level tinkering
was going on. And perhaps it is, as the recently

released synopsis for Avengers Age of Ultron
seems to indicate the following workaround

- Pym still creates the Ultron technology,
but Stark is the one who evolves it - accidentally

creating Ultron and having to deal with the
consequences and guilt. Quite the storyline

and character arc Downey has snagged for himself
there - as comic book fans can confirm having

watched Pym go through it on the page! And
there's more! Beware, this is a potential

spoiler...okay...rumor has it that Avengers
Age of Ultron will end in Marvel Civil War,

with Iron Man and Captain America leading
opposing teams! A rumor which has only been

strengthened by the leak that Downey is finalizing
a deal to appear in Captain America 3 - where

he was only supposed to have a small role
yet lobbied to co-star, and won! And just

like that, Downey has found a way to not only
co-opt the success of Captain\'a0America The

Winter Soldier, but now there would be an
overlying narrative that refers to him throughout

all the MCU movies in Phase Three, which would
see this Civil War play out and then lead

into Avengers 3 and Thanos, the big bad who
brings them all back together. For more on

this, be sure to check out my video all about
a potential MCU Civil War, the link is in

the video description. Then don't forget Tony
Stark's father Howard, introduced in both

Captain America The First Avenger and Iron
Man 2. He's also becoming a thread woven throughout

the MCU, which of course even further ties
these different storylines and elements to

Tony. Howard Stark will be a character on
TV series Agent Carter as well as in the upcoming

film Ant-Man where he presumably crosses paths
with...Hank Pym! Does that mean Papa Stark

helped create the Ultron technology? By the
way, a flesh and blood Jarvis will also show

up in Agent Carter, causing audiences watching
the show to think of Tony and how Jarvis eventually

ended up as his A.I. Then there's Guardians
of the Galaxy, which at first glance might

seem like a threat to Downey's domination.
But if you can't beat 'em join 'em, which

might be exactly what Downey's ALSO planning.
He's publicly stated that Guardians of the

Galaxy is the best Marvel movie to date, but
don't forget that in the recent relaunch of

the Guardians of the Galaxy comic, Tony Stark
joined the team. Beyond the films we know

Marvel has planned, we also shouldn't be surprised
if Tony Stark shows up in any stand-alone

Hulk films thanks to that Science Bros connection.
And at this point, maybe Stephen Strange will

start out as Stark's doctor! With all storylines
leading to Tony, what will happen when Downey

finally says peace out for real? Will he?
Should Marvel recast, or focus on a new character

- or characters? Does the MCU need a focal
point? And is Feige servicing the story with

these choices, or an actor's demands? Is Downey's
involvement in Captain America 3 a step too

far? Finally, what does the popularity of
Guardians of the Galaxy do to this equation?

Will Marvel's Cosmic Cinematic Universe remain
largely separate, or should it fold into our

Earth-bound storylines? And if so, do you
want to see Downey join the team? Be sure

to write your thoughts down below. I'm Grace
Randolph\'a0and this has been a Movie Byte!
You can watch more, right now!

title: Avengers Age of Ultron, Civil War, Captain America 3 : ALL IRON MAN! - Beyond The Trailer
